javaslang.algebra

Interface Monad<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - component type of this monad
    All Superinterfaces:
    Functor<T>, Iterable<T>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Arbitrary<T>, Either<L,R>, Future<T>, Gen<T>, IndexedSeq<T>, Iterator<T>, Lazy<T>, LinearSeq<T>, List<T>, Map<K,V>, Match.MatchMonad<R>, Option<T>, Seq<T>, Set<T>, SortedMap<K,V>, SortedSet<T>, Stack<T>, Stream<T>, Traversable<T>, Tree<T>, Try<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Array, CharSeq, Either.Left, Either.LeftProjection, Either.Right, Either.RightProjection, HashMap, HashSet, Lazy.Defined, Lazy.Undefined, LinkedHashMap, LinkedHashSet, List.Cons, List.Nil, Match.MatchMonad.Otherwise, Match.MatchMonad.Then, Option.None, Option.Some, Queue, Stream.Cons, Stream.Empty, Tree.Empty, Tree.Node, TreeMap, TreeSet, Try.Failure, Try.Success, Vector

    public interface Monad<T>
extends Functor<T>, Iterable<T>
    Defines a Monad by generalizing the flatMap function.

    A Monad is a Functor with a flatMap method that satisfies the Monad laws, also known as the three control laws:

    Let

    • A, B, C be types
    • unit: A -> Monad<A> a constructor
    • f: A -> Monad<B>, g: B -> Monad<C> functions
    • a be an object of type A
    • m be an object of type Monad<A>
    Then all instances of the Monad interface should obey the three control laws:
    • Left identity: unit(a).flatMap(f) ≡ f a
    • Right identity: m.flatMap(unit) ≡ m
    • Associativity: m.flatMap(f).flatMap(g) ≡ m.flatMap(x -> f.apply(x).flatMap(g))
    The left identity `unit(a).flatMap(f) ≡ f.apply(a)` can't be satisfied for single-valued monads.

    Example: 

     
 // = Try(1)
 Try.success(20).flatMap(i -> List.of(1, 2, 3));
    To fix this, we change the flatMap method by adding a unit function: 
     flatMap(f) := unit(map(f).flatten())
    where unit
    • takes the first element (if present), if the underlying Monad is single-valued
    • takes all elements (if any is present), if the underlying Monad is multi-valued
    To read further about monads in Java please refer to What's Wrong in Java 8, Part IV: Monads.
    Since:
    1.1.0
    Author:
    Daniel Dietrich

      • flatMap

        <U> Monad<U> flatMap(Function<? super T,? extends Iterable<? extends U>> mapper)
        FlatMaps this Monad to a new Monad with different component type.

        FlatMap is the sequence operation for functions and behaves like the imperative ;.

        If the previous results are needed, flatMap cascades: 

         
 m1().flatMapM(result1 ->
      m2(result1).flatMapM(result2 ->
          m3(result1, result2).flatMapM(result3 ->
              ...
          )
      )
 );
        If only the last result is needed, flatMap may be used sequentially: 
         
 m1().flatMapM(this::m2)
     .flatMapM(this::m3)
     .flatMapM(...);
        Type Parameters:
        U - Component type of the mapped Monad
        Parameters:
        mapper - A mapper
        Returns:
        a mapped Monad
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if mapper is null

      • unit

        <U> Monad<U> unit(Iterable<? extends U> iterable)
        Creates a new instance of this Monad. If this Monad is single-valued (like Option an Try), only the first value of the given iterable is taken.
        Type Parameters:
        U - component type of the resulting Monad
        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        Returns:
        a new Monad instance
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if mapper is null
